properties.media:imagetext:
(Family Letter No. 3)
Tokyo
January 26, 1950
Dear Family,
I left Bangkok on the morning of the 21st, arriving
Hongkong
that afternoon.
Won't attempt to report on
Siam as
I'm sure Debby and Hebe will write fully.
I did accept an
invitation to go to a Siamese-style prizefight from which I
managed - with some difficulty
- to extricate Debby and Hebe,
only
to learn by letter from Debby that Hebe accepted an in-
vitation from one of her boyfriends to go to a worse one on
the Sunday after I left.
The fights are prefaced by each con-
testant bowing in prayer; then he goes
through a pantomime
routine to show the fans what he is going to do to his opponent -
and how.
The fighters wear gloves but no shoes, and anything
goes except biting in
the
clinches, if they get caught at it!
They kick - either above or below the waist - use their knees,
butt with their heads and flay their opponent with their elbows.
The pace is terrific and knockouts numerous.
I know you'll want to hear about poor old CNAC.
I haven't
written earlier because I didn't know the whole story myself
until I talked to Bond at Hongkong.
When Bond and I returned to New York in December we
got a fix from PAA as to what course we might pursue,
then
Our American
staff in CNAC had agreed unanimously that they would not go along
with the new regime in China unless and until such cooperation
was approved by our State Department.
Furthermore, we knew that
the British were soon going to recognize the Red government of
China.
Therefore, we were faced with the necessity of knowing
what our Government wanted us to do if a new Managing Director
walked into Hongkong and started giving orders as the represen-
tative of the Chinese Reds.
We asked the question,
"Shall we
go along or not?
If not, as PAA how about the American staff?
Do you want such of them as are willing to join the new regime
do you want them to refuse to cooperate?
We must know and
we have a right to expect an answer."
The officials to whom we
talked agreed that we were entitled to an answer but said - in
State Department language - that it was a very hot potato.
They
would try to give us an answer within a few days, and Bond would
stand by in Washington to get said answer.
That was on Thursday,
December 15th.
The following day I left for Paris.
December 19th,
the Department advised Bond that they did not
want us to go along with the Chinese Communists, nor did they
want Americans to offer technical or advisory assistance.
the same time Bond heard that the National Government of
Kai-shek had sold its 80% interest in CNAC to General Chennault.
Bond immediately got in touch with his friend, T.V. Soong, and
made a deal to sell our 20% to the National Government for
properties.wof:name: correspondence: Harold M. Bixby, family circular letter
